image.altText: a close-up of a person holding several pages of a household power bill in their hands

items.synopsis: Every Queensland household will have power bills slashed as part of $1.6 billion in new cost-of-living relief being rolled out in the state budget.

title.children: Power bill rebates and free kindy: $1.6b in new cost-of-living relief announced for Queenslanders

image.altText: Queensland budget winners and losers 2021 illustration

items.synopsis: Powered by a windfall of coal and oil royalties, the Queensland budget for 2023/24 has seen cash splashed across a number of areas.

title.children: Who are the winners and losers in this year's Queensland budget?

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a black hoodie

items.synopsis: Brett Andrew Button, 58, has been released with strict conditions after being granted bail by Cessnock Local Court on Tuesday morning.

title.children: Bus driver 'happy to be going home' after being granted bail over fatal wedding bus crash

image.altText: Minister in his work office

items.synopsis: The Albanese government wants to make quality financial advice far more affordable for households.

title.children: The government is announcing the biggest financial advice shake-up in years. Here's what it could mean for you

image.altText: a young brunette woman smiling into the camera

items.synopsis: Twenty-four-year-old Julia-Mary Lane, who is known as JM, has been living in Canada since early January and is heading into her third night in the wilderness of British Columbia.

title.children: Family fears for Australian woman missing after going hiking in Canadian bear country

image.altText: Gallagher speaks on the senate floor.

items.synopsis: Senator Gallagher fiercely denies she misled parliament over statements she made in relation to Brittany Higgins, telling the Senate that recent events have harmed progress in making parliament safer.

title.children: Katy Gallagher offers full denial to Senate over Brittany Higgins allegations

image.altText: A man with white hair and blue suite poses for the camera.

items.synopsis: Leslie Ball's car was abandoned at the Townsville Railway Station in the 1990s and his trailer was found burnt out in bushland near his home, but his body has never been found.

title.children: Not enough evidence to solve mystery of WWII veteran's disappearance 30 years ago, coroner finds

image.altText: A large dam spilling water over its edge.

items.synopsis: The state government will spend a total of $1 billion increasing the capacity of a north Queensland dam by 150,000 megalitres.

title.children: $500m allocated to upgrade Queensland's largest dam as cost blowout revealed

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a cap.

items.synopsis: Police, SES volunteers, and neighbours on horseback are carrying out an extensive search of dense bushland in Queensland's South Burnett for the missing 28-year-old.

title.children: Community asked to leave lights on, food out in search for autistic man missing in bushland

image.altText: Jeffrey Brooks, who was found dead at the crayfish farm he worked in 1996, wearing a black and white hat and smiling

items.synopsis: Jeffrey Brooks died after being shot in the chest by a 12-gauge single-barrel shotgun at a Beenleigh crayfish farm.

title.children: Coroner refers 1996 shooting death of marine biologist on Queensland crayfish farm to DPP

image.altText: Marlion Pickett is about to catch the football while running

items.synopsis: Richmond have over-ruled Marlion Pickett and won't play him in Saturday's clash against St Kilda after the dual Tigers premiership hero faced court in Perth.

title.children: Richmond stand down Marlion Pickett as two-time premiership winner faces court

image.altText: A woman voting at night at a cardboard polling booth

items.synopsis: Young people are increasingly concerned about the future of the planet and want to have a say, according to organisers of the Make It 16 campaign.

title.children: Campaign kicks off to lower the compulsory voting age to 16

image.altText: Smoke is rising from a building that has been heavily damaged by a missile strike.

items.synopsis: Russia launched a "massive missile" attack overnight on the central Ukrainian city of Kryvyi Rih, killing at least three people and wounding 25 and damaging civilian infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said early on Tuesday.

title.children: At least three dead, scores wounded after 'massive missile' attack by Russia on civilian buildings in Kryvyi Rih, in central Ukraine

image.altText: Two men crouched over a coffin with a woman wrapped in a sheet inside.

items.synopsis: The 76-year-old woman was declared dead at a hospital in Ecuador after being rushed to the emergency room with a possible stroke and cardio-pulmonary arrest.

title.children: Family hears knocking at woman's wake, opens coffin to find her breathing

image.altText: A Shinkansen bullet train on a track in a city.

items.synopsis: Some 34 countries have high-speed rail or are about to get it. But in the decades since it was first proposed for Australia, no local plan for high-speed rail has got further than the drawing board, writes Philip Laird.

title.children: Four decades and millions spent on studies: Why Australia is still waiting for high-speed trains

image.altText: A statue of a soldier riding a horse on top of a monument with names listed

items.synopsis: One of Australia's most divisive diggers Harry "Breaker" Morant could be in line for a posthumous honour of sorts, more than 120 years after he was executed for war crimes.

title.children: This divisive digger was executed for war crimes — but defenders want his name on a war memorial

image.altText: A close-up of a red fire ant nest.

items.synopsis: The red fire ant, which can be lethal to humans and animals, has been found on the western side of the Great Dividing Range for the first time.

title.children: Dangerous pest that could be 'worse' than the cane toad breaches containment zone

image.altText: The back of a young boy's head, looking toward a teacher at the front of a classroom.

items.synopsis: Queensland schools are increasingly employing people before they're fully qualified to teach classrooms as they face critical workforce shortages.

title.children: Almost 900 Queensland trainees granted approval to teach while not fully qualified

image.altText: Gladstone woman Jemma Manwaring smiling

items.synopsis: Central Queensland hospitals have seen multiple birthing services being pulled, but the health minister says a chronic lack of staff that caused the closures is now being addressed.

title.children: Birthing services return to regional Qld hospital. Jemma is relieved but says the fight isn't over

image.altText: a woman wearing glasses talking into microphones at a press conference

items.synopsis: Kate Jenkins, who led the inquiry into the culture of parliament, says the workplace has improved — but warns of the potential damage being done to victims of sexual assault by recent reporting.

title.children: 'It has changed': Kate Jenkins says parliament culture is getting better

image.altText: People stand over a map of the world.

items.synopsis: With only 24 hours in a day, researchers have crunched the numbers and worked out what the average global human day looks like.

title.children: This is what the average human day looks like. How do Australians compare?

image.altText: A composite image of three people on stage wearing long gowns

items.synopsis: This year's Tony Awards were almost cancelled because of the Writers Guild of America strike blazing through Hollywood. But the show must go on — and so it did.

title.children: No scripts and a win for inclusivity — Tony Awards make history amidst Hollywood's writer's strike

image.altText: Black a frame with sign saying fever clinic and a yellow arrow, sitting in front of a red wall with 'emergency' written on it

items.synopsis: Each Omicron wave has had distinguishing features and Australia's fifth wave has grown so slowly many may not have realised it had begun. So why has this most recent wave been so drawn out, and what has its impact been on our health and health systems?

title.children: Australia is in another COVID wave, but it's not like the others

image.altText: First-term Labor MP Michelle Ananda-Rajah sits in parliament.

items.synopsis: Labor backbencher Michelle Ananda-Rajah said on Q+A that there are 122,000 people sleeping rough. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked first-term Labor MP Michelle Ananda-Rajah on rough sleepers. Here's what we found

image.altText: A statue of Lady Justice at Old Bailey central criminal court in London.

items.synopsis: A 44-year-old mother of three has been sentenced to more than two years in an English prison for medically inducing an abortion about eight months into her pregnancy.

title.children: Mother in England jailed for 28 months after medicated abortion later in pregnancy

image.altText: Rear and side of a Victoria Police divisional van. Taken March 2023

items.synopsis: Police launch an appeal for witnesses and anyone with dashcam footage after a woman is found injured in Melbourne's north-east, with no recollection of how she came to leave her home.

title.children: Police baffled after Melbourne woman found naked and injured on street with no memory of what happened

image.altText: A close up shot of a man wearing glasses and a baseball cap

items.synopsis: The 23-year-old man accused of running down Perth police officer Anthony Woods faces court as the charge against him is upgraded to murder.

title.children: Man who allegedly mowed down police officer faces murder charge in Perth court

image.altText: A composite image including the Karen's Diner sign and a notice on the door showing a termination of the lease.

items.synopsis: Viral social media restaurants Karen's Diner close, leaving former workers alleging sexual and physical harassment claims in doubt.

title.children: Karen's Diner employees' concerns remain unresolved as liquidators appointed to multiple restaurants

image.altText: A Denver NBA player smiles and puts his hands on his head in celebration after his team wins a title.

items.synopsis: Denver Nuggets clinch their first-ever NBA title, with a win over the Miami Heat at home as Serbian superstar Nikola Jokić leads the way.

title.children: Denver Nuggets clinch first NBA title with win over Miami Heat

image.altText: A Golden Globe award, shaped like a globe on a pedestal with a strip of movie film wrapped around it.

items.synopsis: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA) sells the Golden Globes to private investors, spelling the end of the embattled non-profit after 80 years of handing out the entertainment awards.

title.children: Golden Globes to become a 'commercial enterprise' as the Hollywood Foreign Press group disbands

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump walks up stairs to board a large aircraft with TRUMP written on the side in gold letters.

items.synopsis: Supporters gather outside a Miami golf club the former president owns, while Mr Trump calls for a planned protest outside the courthouse where he is due to face charges and surrender to authorities.

title.children: Donald Trump arrives in Florida to face charges in documents case

image.altText: High pressure hoses blasting through the surface of a dried up dam

items.synopsis: Sibayne Stillwater sets up shop in Australia citing a "robust and high-quality mining industry" and strong opportunities as it shifts to green energy.

title.children: Global South African miner buys outback Queensland mine
